Description: Digital photograph (colour); view of inscribed graffiti in capitalised Roman and Arabic script, on a sandstone rock face. On the column of rock in the foreground left is written "ABEL" and underneath "JERUSALEM". Below this is "FR...SLM..." and to the lower left of this a collection of letters including "D...", "I", "c", "L", "...", "...", "...", and "M/..." one below the other. Below this is a date: "1937", and below this the letters "A L". At the base of this column is "Xl" with a square symbol between the letters and to the top right is Arabic "الب" ("Alb" [interrupted]). Across a fissure in the rock, to the right, is the word "HILL" in large letters, with "HEWETSON" written above it and "NEGROA" written below. To the right is Arabic: "محمد احمد يايكر" ("Mohamed Ahmed Yayker"). There are further letters to the right of this, illegible due to the slope of the rock face away from the camera. On the next projecting rock column to the right is the Arabic "الب" ("Basheer") and several illegible roman letters. Cave of Swimmers, Egypt. Scanned
Curator's comments: Wadi Sura (also spelled Sora) is a valley on the western edge of the Gilf Kebir plateau in Egypt’s western desert. There, two shallow caves lie on the right at the entrance to the inlet, one smaller than the other and both containing rock paintings. Hans Rhotert designated the caves C and D. Cave C is the larger and contains the paintings of the famous ‘swimming’ figures inspiring those in ‘The English patient’. Cave D, which is close by, contains a single scene of cattle and archers. These caves were discovered, and the valley named, in 1933 by László Almásy. There are several other rock art sites nearby, some discovered by Almásy and Rhotert in the same year, or by P. A. Clayton in 1931, and several which have subsequently been found and documented by Giancarlo Negro, Yves Gauthier, Werner Lenz, András Zboray, Werner Lenz and others.
Associated places: Topographic representation of: Cave of Swimmers
Acquisition name: Donated by: Trust for African Rock Art
